dublin_core.dcvalue: OBJECTIVE The present work investigated reciprocal longitudinal associations between media use physical activity and adolescents psychological health METHODS Data were collected between 2011 and 2017 in the LIFE Child study in Germany The sample included 814 10 to 17 year old adolescents The participants had provided information on their media use hours of TV video computer internet and mobile phone use per day physical activity frequency of organized and non organized physical activity per week behavioral difficulties emotional problems conduct problems hyperactivity inattention peer relationship problems and quality of life physical and psychological wellbeing satisfaction with parents peers and school at two time points 12 months apart Multiple regressions were applied to analyze reciprocal longitudinal associations between media use physical activity and behavioral difficulties quality of life RESULTS Frequent use of computer internet at baseline was associated with an increase in internalizing behavioral difficulties emotional problems and peer relationship problems at follow up Additionally a high frequency of computer internet and mobile phone use was related to a decrease in psychological wellbeing whereas a high frequency of organized physical activity was linked to improved physical wellbeing The analyses also revealed a link between more behavioral difficulties at baseline and an increased TV consumption at follow up CONCLUSION The present work suggests mutual dependencies between electronic media use and psychological health over time
Made available in DSpace on 2020-06-08T14:19:18Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 2-11-30
Reciprocal longitudinal associations between adolescents' media consumption and psychological health.
